''AFA Journal''. May 2001. Retrieved on September 15, 2007.</ref><ref name="ALA1">"[http://www.ala.org/ala/alonline/currentnews/newsarchive/1998/june1998/cyberpatrolblocks.cfm CyberPatrol Blocks Conservative Christian Site over Anti-Gay Content]." [[American Library Association]]. June 1998. Retrieved on September 15, 2007.</ref><ref name=mediatrans>[http://www.mediatransparency.com/story.php?storyID=189 Still Cranky After All These Years]." [[Media Transparency]]. 2007-04-19. Retrieved on June 15, 2007</ref><ref>"[http://money.cnn.com/2005/06/01/Autos/ford_gays/index.htm Conservative Christian group calls boycott of automaker, charging it has pro-homosexual agenda]." [[CNN]]. 2006-06-01. Retrieved on November 15, 2007.</ref> It [[opponents of same-sex marriage in the United States|opposes same-sex marriage]], [[anti-pornography movement|pornography]], and [[pro-life movement|abortion]].<ref name=afagen>[http://action.afa.net/Detail.aspx?id=31 Who is AFA?]. American Family Association. Retrieved on June 17, 2007.</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/OPINION/10/27/sharlet.tea.party.evangelical/index.html |last=Sharlet |first=Jeff |work=CNN |title=Is the Tea Party becoming a religious movement? |date=October 27, 2010 |accessdate=June 14, 2012}}</ref> It also takes a position on a variety of other [[public policy]] goals such as [[deregulation]] of the oil industry{{Citation needed|date=October 2012}} and has lobbied against the [[Employee Free Choice Act]].<ref>[http://action.afa.net/Detail.aspx?id=2147483708 Don't let Obama take away the right to vote by secret ballot], ''AFA Activism.''</ref> It was founded in 1977 by [[Donald Wildmon]] as the '''National Federation for Decency''' and is headquartered in [[Tupelo, Mississippi]].
The AFA defined itself as "a Christian organization promoting the [[Bible|biblical]] ethic of decency in American society with primary emphasis on television and other media," later switching their stated emphasis to "moral issues that impact the family."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aclu-wa.org/detail.cfm?id=149|title=The Religious Right in Washington|date=June 1, 1995|accessdate=June 24, 2007|publisher=[[American Civil Liberties Union|ACLU]]|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070403192146/http://www.aclu-wa.org/detail.cfm?id=149 |archivedate = April 3, 2007}}</ref><ref>http://www.afajournal.org/2003/february/tim.asp</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://media.afa.net/newdesign/about.asp|title=afaMEDIA, About AFA|publisher=American Family Association|accessdate=May 26, 2012}}</ref> It engages in activism efforts, including boycotts, [[buycott]]s, [[action alert]] emails, publications on the AFA's web sites or in the ''AFA Journal'', broadcasts on [[American Family Radio]], and [[lobbying]].<ref>"[http://www.glaad.org/publications/archive_detail.php?id=3818 'American Family Association' Attacks Ford's Family-Friendly Policies After Failed Disney Boycott]." [[Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation|GLADD]]. 2005-06-01. Retrieved on June 17, 2007.</ref> The organization is accredited by the [[Evangelical Council for Financial Accountability]] (ECFA) and posted a 2011 budget of over US$16 million.<ref>[http://www.ecfa.org/MemberProfile.aspx?ID=11259 ECFA budget report]- Retrieved 2012-09-25</ref> AFA owns 200 American Family Radio stations in 33 states, seven affiliate stations in seven states, and one affiliate TV station KAZQ TV) in [[New Mexico]].<ref>[http://www.afa.net/uploadedFiles/Radio/Station%20Listing.pdf AFR radio and TV stations]- Retrieved 2012-09-25</ref><ref name=stonevaida>Peter H Stone, Bara Vaida, "Christian Soldiers" ''National Journal''. Washington, Dec 4, 2004. Volume 36, Issue 49, pg. 3596</ref>
AFA has been listed as a [[hate group]] by the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] as of November 2010 for the "propagation of known falsehoods" and the use of "demonizing propaganda" against [[LGBT]] people.<ref name="urlActive Anti-Gay Groups | Southern Poverty Law Center">{{cite web |url=http://www.splcenter.org/get-informed/intelligence-files/ideology/anti-gay/active_hate_groups |title=Active Anti-Gay Groups | Southern Poverty Law Center |accessdate=April 20, 2011| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20110421184350/http://www.splcenter.org/get-informed/intelligence-files/ideology/anti-gay/active_hate_groups| archivedate= April 21, 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://thenewamerican.com/culture/family/item/641-splc-targets-18-%E2%80%9Canti-gay-pro-family-groups |title=SPLC Targets 18 "Anti-Gay" Pro-family Groups |work=The New American |date=December 3, 2010 |first=Dave |last=Bohon |accessdate=April 21, 2011}}</ref>
== Operations == Reverend [[Donald Wildmon]] served as chairman of AFA until he announced his retirement on March 3, 2010. His son, Tim, is president of AFA. AFA is governed by an independent Board of Directors. ''AFA Journal'' is a monthly publication with a circulation of 180,000<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pfaw.org/pfaw/general/default.aspx?oid=3796|title=Right Wing Organization: American Family Association|publisher=[[People for the American Way]]|accessdate=June 25, 2007| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20070704023846/http://www.pfaw.org/pfaw/general/default.aspx?oid=3796| archivedate= July 04 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> containing news, features, columns, and interviews. In addition to the publication, ''AFA Journal'' articles are made available online. The journal reviews the content of prime-time television shows, categorizing them based on profanity, sex, violence, homosexuality, substance abuse, "anti-Christian" content, or "[[political correctness]]". The categorization is accompanied by short descriptions of the content of the episode under review. The review also lists the advertisers of each show and invites readers to contact the advertisers or television networks to express concern over program content.<ref name="MG">Mathewes-Green, Frederica. "[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3647/is_199703/ai_n8753654 While TV moguls dither, parents' guides deliver Policy Review.]" [[Policy Review]]. Mar/Apr 1997. Iss. 82; pg. 8, 4 pgs. Retrieved on October 2, 2007</ref>
''[[American Family Radio]]'' (AFR) is a network of approximately 200 AFA-owned radio stations broadcasting Christian-oriented programming.<ref name=mediatrans/>
''OneNewsNow.com'' (formerly AgapePress), the AFA news division, provides online audio newscasts and a daily digest of news articles, [[Associated Press]] stories, and opinion columns.<ref>"[http://media.afa.net/newdesign/ReleaseDetail.asp?id=3532 News Operations Merge to Create OneNewsNow.com]" AFA Media. 2007-02-23. Retrieved on June 25, 2007</ref>
''The AFA Foundation'' is a planned giving program that allows participants the ability to set up bequests, charitable gift annuities, trusts and wills, that will provide income with tax advantages while supporting charity.<ref>[http://afa.giftlegacy.com/?pageID=1 The AFA Foundation]- Retrieved 2012-09-25</ref> In July 2011 the [[Charity Navigator]] gave the foundation a four star rating for sound fiscal management<ref>[http://afa.giftlegacy.com/org_files/250/pdf/charity_navigator.pdf Charity Navigator]- Retrieved 2012-09-25</ref>
Center for Law and Policy, the legal and political arm of the AFA, was shut down in 2007. It specialized in First Amendment cases. The Center for Law and Policy lobbied legislative bodies, drafted legislation, and filed religious-discrimination lawsuits on behalf of individuals.<ref name=stonevaida/> Chief among its efforts were the recognition of Christmas in seasonal print advertisements; the criminalization of homosexuality;<ref>The AFA filed an amicus curiae brief in Lawrence vs Texas, arguing against repeal: [http://supreme.justia.com/us/539/558/case.html Lawrence v. Texas – 539 U.S. 558 (2003)]</ref><ref name="sovo">{{cite news|first=Dyana|last=Bagby|url=http://www.sovo.com/2005/6-3/news/national/anti-gay.cfm|title=Efforts of 'anti-gay industry' chronicled in new report|work=[[Southern Voice (newspaper)|Southern Voice]]|date=June 3, 2005|accessdate=June 25, 2007 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070213062906/http://www.sovo.com/2005/6-3/news/national/anti-gay.cfm |archivedate = February 13, 2007}}</ref><ref name=vanderkam>Vanderkam, Laura R. "Internet filter blocks anti-gay Web sites". ''[[The Washington Times]]'' (1998-08-05) {{ISSN|07328494}}. [[ProQuest]] ID:32625145</ref> lobbying against [[same-sex marriage]], and in opposition of equal-rights and hate-crime legislation that would include sexual orientation and gender identity under categories already protected<ref>[http://www.afa.net/homosexual_agenda/homosexuality.pdf Homosexuality] AFA website guide to homosexuality</ref><ref>[http://www3.capwiz.com/afanet/issues/bills/?bill=9642666 AFA opposition to S.1105, an act which would strengthen hate-crime legislation] AFA legal action website</ref><ref>[http://www3.capwiz.com/afanet/issues/bills/?bill=10434601 AFA opposition to HR3685, an act which would prohibit employment discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation] AFA legal action website</ref> and advocating censorship of print and electronic media.<ref>Boston, Rob. "[http://www.thefreelibrary.com/The+religious+right+and+American+freedom%3A+fundamentalist+christian...-a0147520507 The Religious Right and American Freedom]". ''Church & State''. June 2006 Retrieved on February 7, 2008.</ref>
==Campaigns and issues== The AFA has a history of activism by organizing its members in boycotts and letter-writing campaigns aimed at promoting socially conservative values in the United States. The AFA has promoted boycotts of a number of television shows, movies, and businesses that the group considers to have promoted [[indecency]], [[obscenity]], or homosexuality. In addition to promoting activism via mail to AFA members, 3.4 million subscribers receive AFA "Action Alerts" via email.<ref name=mediatrans/>
=== Boycotts === The AFA has boycotted companies for various reasons, most often relating to [[Christmas controversy|Christmas controversies]], pornography, support of [[pro-choice]] activism, support of violence or sexual content in entertainment, and support of [[LGBT]] activism, including same-sex partner employee benefits. These organizations include: [[7-Eleven]], [[Abercrombie & Fitch]], [[American Airlines]], [[American Girl (company)|American Girl]], [[Blockbuster Video]], [[Burger King]], [[Calvin Klein]], [[Carl's Jr.]], [[Clorox]], [[Comcast]], [[Crest (toothpaste)|Crest]], [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]], [[Hallmark Cards]], [[Kmart]], [[Kraft Foods]], [[S. C. Johnson & Son]], [[Movie Gallery]], [[Microsoft]], MTV, [[Mary Kay Cosmetics|Mary Kay]], [[Nutrisystems Diet|NutriSystem]], [[Old Navy]], [[IKEA]], [[Sears]], [[Pampers]], [[Procter & Gamble]], [[Target Corporation|Target]], [[Tide]], [[Walt Disney Company]], and [[PepsiCo]]. The AFA has criticized the People's Republic of China for its persecution of Christians.<ref>"''Update: CHINA: Executed for Distributing Bibles'' AFA Action Alert May 26, 2005"</ref><ref>"''China: Executed for Distributing Bibles'' AFA Action Alert Dec 14, 2004"</ref><ref>"''Would you go to prison for your faith?'' AFA Action Alert Sep 28, 2004"</ref>
In 1986, 7-Eleven stopped selling ''[[Playboy]]'' and ''[[Penthouse (magazine)|Penthouse]]'' magazines after a two-year boycott by the AFA.<ref name=liebeck>Liebeck, Laura. "[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m3092/is_n9_v29/ai_9076835 K mart, Waldenbooks to face AFA pickets]". ''Discount Store News''. 1990-05-07 Retrieved on July 15, 2007.</ref> In 1989 the AFA boycotted [[Waldenbooks|WaldenBooks]] in an attempt to persuade the company to stop selling those same magazines. As a result, WaldenBooks launched an advertisement campaign against censorship, asserting [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] rights. WaldenBooks, [[American Booksellers Association]], the Council for Periodical Distributors Association, the International Periodical Distributors Association, and Duval Bibb Services launched a lawsuit against the AFA in October 1989, under the [[Federal government of the United States|Federal]] [[Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act]] (RICO) and the [[Florida|Florida State]] RICO Acts, which protect an organization's right to conduct business without harassment or threats.<ref name=liebeck>Cohen, Roger. "[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CEEDD1431F930A15757C0A966958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=print With Boycott and Ads, A Battle Over Selling]". ''[[The New York Times]]''. 1990-04-23. Retrieved on September 29, 2007.</ref> The case was settled by the parties without a court ruling.
Christian Leaders for Responsible Television (CLeaR-TV), affiliated with the AFA, has approached sponsors of programs that it considered immoral. In 1989, CLeaR-TV successfully persuaded [[General Mills]], [[Ralston Purina]], [[Domino's Pizza]], [[Mazda]], and [[Noxell]] to withdraw advertising from ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''.<ref>{{harvnb|Hunter|1991|pp=228, 236}}</ref> AFA also boycotted [[PepsiCo]] that year also for supporting [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], whose video for "[[Like a Prayer]]" Wildmon felt was sacrilegious.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,957949,00.html|title=Interview with Rev. Donald E. Wildmon: Bringing Satan To Heel|last=Winbush|first=Don|date=June 19, 1989|work=Time|accessdate=July 18, 2009}}</ref>
During the summer of 1993 the AFA purchased full-page ads in ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[USA Today]]'', and ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' denouncing the sexual and violent content of the upcoming [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] police drama ''[[NYPD Blue]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Carter|first=Bill|title=Police Drama Under Fire for Sex and Violence|url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CE1DF133FF931A15755C0A965958260|work=The New York Times|date=June 22, 1993|accessdate=August 1, 2008}}</ref> It also urged ABC affiliates not to broadcast the program and citizens to boycott sponsors of ''Blue''. About a quarter of the 225 existing ABC stations followed suit, but such affiliates were mostly in rural areas of the US. The AFA campaign increased hype for the show in larger American media markets, and ''Blue'' became one of the most popular shows of the [[1993–94 United States network television schedule|1993–1994 television season]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Streible|first=Daniel G.|title=NYPD Blue|url=http://www.museum.tv/archives/etv/N/htmlN/nypdblue/nypdblue.htm|publisher=Museum of Broadcast Communications|accessdate=August 1, 2008}}</ref> In 1996, the AFA launched a boycott against [[Walt Disney Company]] when the company began giving benefits to same-sex employees in domestic partnerships. The AFA has claimed that [[Michael Eisner]], the CEO of The Disney Company, "was involved in a media group that actively promoted the homosexual agenda" and was pushing the "gay agenda". The AFA ended the unsuccessful nine-year boycott in spring 2005 after Eisner left the company.<ref name=MSNBCford2>Johnson, Alex"[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/8119504/ns/business-us_business Christian group suspends Ford boycott]". [[MSNBC]] 2005-06-06. Retrieved on June 24, 2007</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.365gay.com/newscon05/05/052405disney.htm |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060210152335/http://www.365gay.com/newscon05/05/052405disney.htm |archivedate=February 10, 2006 |title=Anti-Gay Group Ends Disney Boycott |first=Doreen |last=Brandt |publisher=[[365gay News]] |date=May 24, 2005}}</ref><ref>"[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/7968642/ Conservative group ends 9-year Disney boycott]". [[Associated Press]] (Published on [[MSNBC]]). 2005-05-24. Retrieved on September 29, 2007.</ref> Tim Wildmon stated "We feel after nine years of boycotting Disney we have made our point."<ref>[http://www.bpnews.net/bpnews.asp?id=20841 AFA ends Disney boycott it launched in mid-1990s], Dwayne Hastings, ''Baptist Press'', 2005-05-24. Retrieved on November 22, 2010</ref>
In 2003, the AFA, with the [[American Decency Association]], [[Focus on the Family]], and Citizens for Community Values, lobbied and boycotted [[Abercrombie & Fitch]], calling on "A&F to stop using blatant pornography in its quarterly catalog."<ref>Pugh, Rusty and Parker, Jenni. [http://headlines.agapepress.org/archive/12/afa/102003a.asp Decency Advocates Claim Victory as A&F Pulls Explicit Catalog, Ceases Publication]. AFA Journal. 2003-12-10. Retrieved on 2007-06-16. ([http://web.archive.org/web/20060827201613/http://headlines.agapepress.org/archive/12/afa/102003a.asp archived link])</ref> In December 2003, the company "recalled the holiday catalog from all its stores, saying it needed the space on the counter for a new perfume" and stated it would stop printing catalogs and start a new campaign.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://money.cnn.com/2003/12/09/news/companies/abercrombie/index.htm | title=Abercrombie kills its racy catalog | date=December 9, 2003 | work=CNN | first=Parija | last=Bhatnagar}}</ref>
In 2005 the AFA boycotted the company [[American girl dolls|American Girl]], seller of dolls and accessories, because the company supported the charity [[Girls, Inc.]], which the AFA called "a pro-abortion, pro-lesbian advocacy group".<ref>"[http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2005-10-14-american-girl_x.htm Conservatives protest popular doll-maker]". [[Associated Press]] (Published on [[USA Today]]). 2005-10-15. Retrieved on October 1, 2007.</ref>
In Spring 2005 the AFA launched a boycott of [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] for advertising in gay magazines, donating to [[gay rights]] organizations, and sponsoring [[gay pride]] celebrations.<ref name=MSNBCford2/><ref name=NPRford>"[http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5041397 Ford Drops Ads in Gay-Oriented Magazines]". [[National Public Radio|NPR]]. 2005-12-06. Retrieved on October 1, 2007.</ref><ref>Johnson, Alex. "[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/8047423/ Another swing of the pocketbook: Christian activist groupgoes after Ford Motor Co.]". [[MSNBC]]. June 1, 2005</ref> After meeting with representatives of the group, Ford announced it was curtailing ads in a number of major gay-themed publications, due not by cultural but by "cost-cutting" factors. That statement was contradicted by the AFA, which claimed it had a "good faith agreement" that Ford would cease such ads. Soon afterwards, as a result of a strong outcry from the gay community, Ford backtracked and announced it would continue ads in gay publications, in response to which the AFA denounced Ford for "violating" the agreement, and renewed threats of a boycott.<ref name="fordca">{{Cite news |url=http://www.consumeraffairs.com/news04/2005/ford_gay_ads04.html |title=Anti-Gay Group Renews Ford Boycott Threat |date=December 17, 2005 |accessdate=May 4, 2007 |periodical=ConsumerAffairs.com |ref=harv |postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> The boycott ended in March 2008.<ref>[http://www.consumeraffairs.com/news04/2008/03/ford_antigay.html Hate Groups End Ford Boycott], Joe Benton, ''Consumer Affairs'', 2008-03-11. Retrieved on November 22, 2010</ref>
On [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]] 2008, the AFA announced a boycott of [[McDonald's]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Ahrens|first=Frank|title=Gay-Marriage Opponents To Boycott McDonald's|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/07/03/AR2008070303769.html|work=The Washington Post|page=D1|date=July 4, 2008}}</ref> which had a director on the board of the [[National Gay and Lesbian Chamber of Commerce]]. In October 2008, AFA announced the end of its boycott following the declaration to be "neutral on same-sex marriage or any 'homosexual agenda' as defined by the American Family Association" by McDonald's in a memo to franchisees.<ref>[http://www.suntimes.com/business/1213469,CST-NWS-gaymcd10.article McDonald's cuts off gay chamber of commerce group]{{dead link|date=March 2012}}</ref>
On August 25, 2008, the AFA announced their boycott of [[Hallmark Cards]] for their decision to start selling same-sex wedding cards.<ref>[http://www.afa.net/Petitions/Issuedetail.asp?id=329 "Hallmark pushes same-sex marriage."] AFA website. Retrieved on August 25, 2008.</ref>
In December 2008, the AFA issued an "Action Alert"<ref>[http://www.afa.net/Petitions/Issuedetail.asp?id=337 Campbell Soup Company embraces homosexual agenda] AFA website, retrieved on December 30, 2008</ref> which called for members to protest about the [[Campbell Soup Company]], which had purchased two two-page advertisements in the December 2008 and January 2009 issues of LGBT magazine ''[[The Advocate]]''. The Action Alert said that Campbell's "sent a message that homosexual parents constitute a family and are worthy of support". The advertisements showed a married lesbian couple with their son. AFA spokesman Randy Sharp said "the Campbell Soup Company is saying 'we approve of homosexual marriage.'"<ref>[http://www.onenewsnow.com/Culture/Default.aspx?id=360388 Pro-family group stirred up over Campbell's] onenewsnow.com, Retrieved on December 30, 2008.</ref>
In November 2009, the AFA called for a boycott against clothing retailer [[Gap (clothing retailer)|The Gap, Inc.]], claiming the retailer's holiday television advertising campaign failed to mention Christmas. "Christmas has historically been very good for commerce. But now Gap wants the commerce but no Christmas" wrote an AFA spokesperson. The Gap soon released an advertisement in response to the boycott, specifically referring to Christmas, albeit with a number of other holidays that take place at the same time of year and added the word "Christmas" to in-store decor.<ref>{{cite news|last=Neil|first=Dan|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-ct-neil17-2009nov17,0,2040716.story|title=Gap's Christmas cheer makes a boycott backfire|work=Los Angeles Times|date=November 17, 2009|accessdate=December 16, 2009| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20091120181003/http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-ct-neil17-2009nov17,0,2040716.story?| archivedate= November 20, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite video|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oVMPWlWDvsI|title=Go Ho Ho – Gap 2009 Holiday Commercial|people=Crispin Porter + Bogusky (Producer)|quote=Go Christmas|date=November 13, 2009|accessdate=December 16, 2009}}</ref>
In 2012 they led a failed boycott against [[Archie Comics]] when they published a comic book featuring a [[same-sex marriage]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geeksofdoom.com/2012/03/02/one-million-moms-protest-gay-marriage-in-archie-comic/ |title=One Million Moms Protest Gay Marriage In Archie Comic |publisher=Geeks of Doom |date=March 2, 2012 |accessdate=March 9, 2012}}</ref>
In July 2012, they considered boycotting Google due to Google's "Legalize Love" campaign which supports [[LGBT]] rights.<ref>[http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2012/07/11/video-anti-gay-american-family-association-ponders-google-ban/ Video: Anti-gay American Family Association ponders Google ban] retrieved 13 July 2012</ref>
=== Published media === On April 16, 2007, following the [[Virginia Tech Massacre]], the AFA released a video titled ''The Day They Kicked God out of the Schools'', in which God tells a student that students were killed in schools because God isn't allowed in schools anymore. The video claims that the shootings at [[Virginia Tech massacre|Virginia Tech]] and [[Columbine High School massacre|Columbine]], among others, are in part the result of: decreased discipline in schools; no [[School prayer|prayer in schools]]; sex out of wedlock; rampant violence in TV, movies, and music; or abortions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afr.net/newafr/wekickedgodout.asp|title=The Day They Kicked God out of the Schools|publisher=American Family Radio (American Family Association)|accessdate=June 25, 2007| archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20070708045621/http://www.afr.net/newafr/wekickedgodout.asp| archivedate= July 08 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>"[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3944/is_200706/ai_n19434950 Gingrich Says Liberals And Lack Of Religion Sparked Va. Tech Killings]." ''[[Americans United for Separation of Church and State|Church and State]]''. June 2007. Retrieved on October 1, 2007.</ref>
''[[Speechless: Silencing the Christians]]'' is a 2008 documentary series hosted by [[Janet Parshall]]. The documentary series explains the AFA's position against the drive towards [[political correctness]], and how various factors, such as hate crime laws and other discriminatory actions, are threatening the Christians' existence. In 2009, a one-hour special version of the program was produced and aired on commercial television stations, where AFA purchased the air time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afajournal.org/2008/january/0108afa_insp.asp |title=AFA, INSP partner in new TV series|accessdate=July 20, 2009 |date=2008-01 |work=AFA Journal | archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20090712184650/http://www.afajournal.org/2008/january/0108afa_insp.asp| archivedate= July 12, 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
=== Sexual morality === The AFA has repeatedly lobbied Congress to eliminate funding for the [[National Endowment for the Arts]].<ref name=sherkatellison>Darren E Sherkat, Christopher G Ellison, [http://links.jstor.org/sici?sici=0037-7732%28199703%2975%3A3%3C957%3ATCSOAM%3E2.0.CO%3B2-5 The cognitive structure of a moral crusade: Conservative protestantism and opposition to pornography], ''Social Forces'', Mar 1997. Volume 75, Issue 3 pg. 957 ([http://proquest.umi.com/pqdlink?did=11475013&sid=1&Fmt=4&clientId=20923&RQT=309&VName=PQD ProQuest link])</ref> For example, in 2000, the AFA issued a press release condemning the NEA's funding of ''[[One of the Guys]]'', a controversial book by [[Robert Clark Young]] described by a senior AFA official as "scatological." The complaint from the AFA was that the book included [[sexually explicit]] material, in particular, a description of a young woman extracting razor blades from her vagina during a performance in a [[sex club]]. === Marilyn Manson === Paul Cambria, lawyer for rock band [[Marilyn Manson (band)|Marilyn Manson]], sent a [[cease and desist]] letter to AFA on April 25, 1997 in response to allegations published in the ''AFA Journal'' that Manson encouraged audience members to engage in sexual and violent acts in its concerts. ''AFA Journal'' relied on testimony by two anonymous teenage concertgoers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1432997/19970428/osbourne_ozzy.jhtml|title=Ozzy, Slayer Turn Up On "Ozzfest Live"|date=April 28, 1997|publisher=MTV News|accessdate=July 18, 2009}}</ref> The allegations were independently proven to be false.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.snopes.com/music/artists/marilyn2.asp |title=Dead Puppies |author=Mikkleson, Barbara |date=May 15, 2007 |work=[[Snopes]] |accessdate=June 14, 2010}}</ref> Wildmon responded that his organization as a whole was not responsible, but rather the AFA's Gulf Coast chapter in [[Biloxi, Mississippi]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1426055/19970502/black_sabbath.jhtml|title=Ozzy, Manson File Suit Against Meadowlands|date=May 2, 1997|publisher=MTV News|accessdate=July 18, 2009}}</ref>
===Labeled a hate group=== [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] (SPLC), in a 2005 report, stated that the AFA, along with other groups, engaged in [[hate speech]] to "help drive the religious right's anti-gay crusade."<ref name=Hall2005>{{cite news|url=http://www.crosswalk.com/news/religiontoday/1337955/|first=Randy|last=Hall|date=June 30, 2005|accessdate=June 27, 2009|title=Christian 'Hate Groups' Accused of 'Anti-Gay Crusade'|publisher=Crosswalk.com}}</ref> Mark Potok of the SPLC determined that the turning point was 2003's ''[[Lawrence v. Texas]]'', in which the [[United States Supreme Court|Supreme Court]] struck down Texas's anti-sodomy laws. After that, the Christian right spent millions on advertisements,<ref name=Hall2005/> and on pastor briefings organized by activists such as born-again Christian [[David Lane (activist)|David Lane]].<ref name=Besen2011>{{cite web |url=http://www.fcnp.com/commentary/national/8923-extremism-flying-beneath-the-radar.html |title=Extremism Flying Beneath The Radar |date=April 6, 2011 |last=Besen |first=Wayne |work=Falls Church News Press |publisher=Falls Church News-Press Online |accessdate=April 22, 2011 |quote=Indeed, the AFA's noxious views were on full display this week, when the group's star radio personality, Bryan Fischer, insulted African Americans. 'Welfare has destroyed the African-American family by telling young black women that husbands and fathers are unnecessary and obsolete,' said Fischer. 'Welfare has subsidized illegitimacy by offering financial rewards to women who have more children out of wedlock. We have incentivized fornication rather than marriage, and it's no wonder we are now awash in the disastrous social consequences of people who rut like rabbits.'}}</ref> Lane helped AFA put constitutional opposite-sex marriage amendments on the ballots of 13 states.<ref name=Hall2005/>
